# Sample Environmental Reporting Act

## Article I - Definitions

### Section 101 - General Definitions

For the purposes of this Act, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth below:

"Administrator" means the chief executive officer of the Environmental Protection Agency, or any person designated by the Administrator to perform duties under this Act.

"Affiliate" means any entity that directly or indirectly controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another entity. For purposes of this definition, "control" means ownership of more than fifty percent (50%) of the voting securities of an entity.

"Covered Facility" means any industrial facility that:
(a) emits more than 25,000 metric tons of greenhouse gases annually;
(b) is located within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States; and
(c) is not specifically exempted under Section 301(b).

"Force Majeure" means any event beyond the reasonable control of a party, including but not limited to:
- Natural disasters such as earthquakes, floods, or hurricanes
- Acts of war, terrorism, or civil unrest
- Government actions that make performance impossible
- Epidemics or pandemics declared by recognized health authorities

The term "Force Majeure" shall not include:
- Financial difficulties of the reporting party
- Market conditions affecting profitability
- Acts of negligence by the reporting party

"Reporting Period" means the calendar year for which emissions data is reported, as specified in Section 202.

## Article II - Reporting Requirements

### Section 201 - Annual Reporting Obligations

(a) General Requirement. Each owner or operator of a Covered Facility shall submit an annual emissions report to the Administrator within ninety (90) days following the end of each Reporting Period.

(b) Report Contents. Each report required under subsection (a) shall include:
1. Total greenhouse gas emissions measured in metric tons of CO2 equivalent
2. Emissions by category as specified in the guidelines issued pursuant to Section 203
3. Description of measurement methodologies employed
4. Certification of accuracy signed by a responsible corporate officer

(c) Electronic Submission. All reports shall be submitted electronically through the reporting system designated by the Administrator. See Section 204 for system requirements.

### Section 202 - Reporting Timelines

(a) Standard Deadline. Reports shall be due on March 31 of the year following the Reporting Period.

(b) Extensions. The Administrator may grant extensions of up to sixty (60) days upon demonstration of good cause, provided that:
1. The request is submitted in writing at least thirty (30) days before the standard deadline
2. The request describes the specific circumstances justifying the extension
3. The request includes a proposed compliance timeline

(c) Late Submissions. Failure to submit reports by the applicable deadline (including any approved extensions) may result in penalties as specified in Section 401.

### Section 203 - Reporting Guidelines

The Administrator shall issue guidelines for reporting under this Article within one hundred eighty (180) days of the enactment of this Act. Such guidelines shall:

(a) Establish standardized methodologies for measuring emissions
(b) Define categories of emissions to be reported separately
(c) Specify verification requirements as referenced in Section 204
(d) Provide templates and examples for Covered Facility operators

### Section 204 - Verification Requirements

(a) Third-Party Verification. Reports submitted under Section 201 shall be verified by an independent third-party verifier accredited by the Administrator.

(b) Verifier Qualifications. Third-party verifiers must:
1. Hold appropriate professional certifications as determined by the Administrator
2. Maintain independence from the Covered Facility being verified
3. Complete training programs approved pursuant to Section 203

## Article III - Compliance

### Section 301 - General Compliance Requirements

(a) Compliance Obligation. All persons subject to this Act shall comply with:
1. All applicable reporting requirements set forth in Article II
2. Verification requirements established under Section 204
3. Record retention requirements specified in Section 302

(b) Exemptions. The following facilities are exempt from the requirements of this Act:
1. Agricultural operations with fewer than one hundred (100) employees
2. Research facilities operated by accredited educational institutions
3. Facilities that qualify under the small emitter threshold defined by the Administrator pursuant to Section 101

### Section 301(a) - Compliance Monitoring

The Administrator shall establish a compliance monitoring program that includes:
- Regular audits of submitted reports
- Site inspections as authorized under Section 303
- Review of verification reports submitted under Section 204

### Section 301(b) - Compliance Assistance

The Administrator shall provide compliance assistance to Covered Facilities, including:
- Technical guidance documents
- Training programs for facility personnel
- A help desk for compliance questions
- Model compliance plans for common facility types

### Section 302 - Record Retention

(a) General Requirement. Each Covered Facility shall maintain records supporting its annual reports for a period of not less than seven (7) years following the submission date.

(b) Record Contents. Records shall include:
1. Original measurement data and calculations
2. Calibration records for measurement equipment
3. Documentation of any Force Majeure events claimed
4. Correspondence with verifiers and the Administrator

### Section 303 - Inspections

(a) Authority. The Administrator, or any duly authorized representative, may enter any Covered Facility at reasonable times to:
1. Inspect and copy records required under Section 302
2. Observe monitoring equipment and procedures
3. Interview facility personnel regarding compliance matters

(b) Notice. Except in cases of emergency or suspected fraud, the Administrator shall provide at least forty-eight (48) hours advance notice before conducting an inspection.

(c) Confidentiality. Information obtained during inspections shall be treated as confidential business information pursuant to Section 501.

## Article IV - Enforcement

### Section 401 - Penalties

(a) Civil Penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this Act may be subject to civil penalties not to exceed:
1. $50,000 per day for failure to submit required reports
2. $25,000 per day for submission of incomplete or inaccurate reports
3. $100,000 per day for falsification of reports or records

(b) Penalty Factors. In determining penalty amounts, the Administrator shall consider:
1. The nature, circumstances, and extent of the violation
2. The violator's ability to pay
3. The violator's prior history of compliance
4. The economic benefit gained through noncompliance

### Section 402 - Administrative Orders

The Administrator may issue administrative orders requiring compliance with this Act. Such orders may include:
- Cease and desist orders
- Orders requiring corrective action
- Orders imposing monitoring or reporting requirements beyond those in Article II

## Article V - Miscellaneous Provisions

### Section 501 - Confidentiality

(a) Treatment of Business Information. Any information submitted to the Administrator that is designated by the submitter as confidential business information shall be protected from public disclosure, except as required by law.

(b) Exceptions. The protections of subsection (a) shall not apply to:
1. Aggregate emissions data that cannot be attributed to individual facilities
2. Information required to be disclosed under other federal law
3. Information already publicly available

### Section 502 - Judicial Review

Any person adversely affected by a final action of the Administrator under this Act may seek judicial review in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

### Section 503 - Effective Date

This Act shall take effect on January 1 of the calendar year following its enactment, provided that:
- Reporting requirements under Article II shall apply beginning with the first full Reporting Period after the effective date
- Guidelines required under Section 203 shall be issued prior to the first applicable Reporting Period
